What are some popular outdoor activities.answer:
Iceland offers a variety of outdoor activities for adventure seekers, including hiking, trail running, and winter sports [1, 2, 4]. The country is known for its comfortable nature trails and challenging multi-day adventures in remote wilderness, with trails running across mountains, valleys, rugged coastlines, moss-grown lava fields, and featuring waterfalls, hot springs, volcanoes, and glaciers [1]. Some popular hiking routes in Iceland are the Laugavegur trail between Landmannalaugar and Þórsmörk, Fimmvörðuháls, Lónsöræfi, Hornstrandir, and Vatnaleið [2].

In addition to hiking, trail running is popular in Iceland due to its mountainous and rugged terrain [2]. For winter sports, Hlíðarfjall in Akureyri and Bláfjall in Reykjavík invite Alpine skiers, snowboarders, and cross-country trackers [4]. Snowshoeing, guided off-track cross-country tours, snowmobiling, and dogsledding are also available [4].

Around Reykjavík, many day trips can be taken to surrounding mountains, glaciers, volcanoes, and hot springs [5]. Other adventure activities include ice and alpine climbing, angling, cycling, glacier climbing, river rafting, caving, and ziplining [3, 5].

During this time, the solar winds interact with atmospheric gases, causing the auroras to appear at altitudes of over 100 kilometres [4]. The best conditions for spotting auroras include a cloudless sky and minimal light pollution [3]. In fact, the Northern Lights are visible for approximately 200 nights a year in Finnish Lapland [6]. Furthermore, frozen lakes in Finland offer great open views for observing the auroras [5].
